item.title: By: brian
item.dc:creator: brian
item.description: I think one of the hardest things is to work out how we could possibly <a href="http://www.stuffit.org/makebankspay-big.jpg" rel="nofollow">re-socialise debt</a>. You're right (of course) about the way that debt mostly keeps us in line, but also has the potential to destabilise (i.e. unfreeze) social relations. It's a disciplining mechanism ("keep your head down, don't cause trouble" etc) but one that could flip ("Aw, fuck it!"). There's an interesting take on it <a href="http://polaris.moviments.net:8000/crisi" rel="nofollow">here</a> (on <a href="http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/2008/09/408879" rel="nofollow">Indymedia</a>) which links back to earlier forms of 'criminality' – not just the era of the <a href="http://www.amazon.co.uk/London-Hanged-Society-Eighteenth-Century/dp/1859845762/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1221734156&sr=1-2" rel="nofollow">London Hanged</a> but more recent times of dole survival in the 1980s which was often supplemented by, ahem, other sources of income. The problem still remains: how do we experience money <em>collectively</em> when it's so often such a <em>private</em> thing...
item.content:encoded: I think one of the hardest things is to work out how we could possibly re-socialise debt. You’re right (of course) about the way that debt mostly keeps us in line, but also has the potential to destabilise (i.e. unfreeze) social relations. It’s a disciplining mechanism (“keep your head down, don’t cause trouble” etc) but one that could flip (“Aw, fuck it!”). There’s an interesting take on it here (on Indymedia) which links back to earlier forms of ‘criminality’ – not just the era of the London Hanged but more recent times of dole survival in the 1980s which was often supplemented by, ahem, other sources of income. The problem still remains: how do we experience money collectively when it’s so often such a private thing…
